Review: Miss Julie

By James Bithell

In a piece underlined by tragedy, modern day South Africa is explored through a simple and ghostly performance by the lead. Francesca Stephenson reviews.

Review: Carmen

By James Bithell

Despite Candyfloss the donkey's best efforts, Carmen at the Grand Opera House lacked the fire and passion it deserved. Emily Heggadon reviews.

Review: 50 Shades of Feminism

By James Bithell

This collection of essays proves elegantly that feminism has its own narrative, language and collective shades of understanding, although fails to take advantage of an empathetic male perspective. Laura Hughes reviews.

Review: Alice's Adventure in Wonderland

By James Bithell

The Royal Opera House shines in a ballet that both honours and parodies the familiarity of classical ballets, with dark and humorous twists at every turn.

Review: Steptoe and Son

Fifty years on from its first airing, the series is adapted for the Lyrics Theatre stage, subtly probing into questions of gender and social standing. Georgia Woodroffe reviews.

Review: Vanessa and Virginia

By James Bithell

The Bloomsbury sisters are examined through vivacious theatre. Ruby Cooper reviews.

Review: One Love at York Literary Festival

By James Bithell

'One Love', York Literary Festival's closing event was a violent clash of art forms, with poets, songwriters and comedians all thrown in together. Sam Hickford reviews.

Review: Aesthetica Art Prize Exhibition

By James Bithell

Review: The Inter-University Drama Festival

York Uni hosts the Inter-University Drama Festival 2013, showcasing student talent from all over the country. Jordan Licht reviews the weekend's action.

Are Opera and Ballet Elitist?

By James Bithell

Ballet and opera have long been seen as the epitome of high culture and art. Amy Blumsom ponders about how, at the end of the day, they're both forms of art.

Review: Mark Hearld: A First Book of Nature

By James Bithell

Roisin Astell finds a modest selection of some of Hearld's finest artworks.

Jonny Walker's Battle for Music and Public Space

By James Bithell

Jonny Walker, busker and wandering troubadour, writes of his battle to save music in public spaces

Review: Dog Days

By James Bithell

A crime becomes news, becoming a film, becoming a play. James Soldan's examination of media action transfixes the Drama Barn with twisted thrill. Lucie Parker reviews.

Review: Play in a Day

Beautifully unironed and endearingly comical, Dramasoc's termly Play in a Day festival is the kind of eccentric fun that so many great men and women grew up on. Sam Hickford reviews.

Manet: Portraying Life

By James Bithell

Lauded as an exhibition that produces a 'blast of fresh air', making the public 'sit up and pay attention', the Royal Academy exhibition has been causing quite a stir in the art world. Roisin Astell reviews.

Review: Wentworth Comedy Festival

By James Bithell

A marathon of stand-up and a showing of York's improv outfit, The Shambles, this Wentworth event show-cased much of the fantastic comic talent that York has to offer.

Review: An evening of Drawing Blood

By James Bithell

This one-night-only exhibition at the Norman Rea Gallery showcased political cartoons from caricaturists who draw between the prescribed lines of state censorship

Review: Oliver!

By James Bithell

Oliver! in York provides a sparkling night of familiar songs and captivating action. Ellie Wright reviews.

Review: The Resistance is Not Futile

Poppy Bullard talks to the Norman Rea's latest artist, Frances Copeman, about her exhibition 'The Resistance is not Futile'.

Review: Breathing Corpses

By James Bithell

Breathing Corpses at York Theatre Royal offers death with a difference. Sonali Dutti reviews.

Review: Running On The Cracks

By James Bithell

A world of converse trainers, Claire's Accessories and a cannon dominated by the authorship of Jacqueline Wilson. Fiona Parker reviews.

The Movements: The Theatre of Cruelty

By James Bithell

Poppy Bullard reviews Antonin Artaud's resounding legacy in contemporary theatre.

Portrait of an Artist: Antony Dunn

By James Bithell

The local poet talks to Fiona Parker about his formative years, translating poetry and life as a poetical subject

Putting Graffiti in Context

By James Bithell

Ben Cross discusses the changing role of Graffiti in society.

Review: A Monster Calls

By James Bithell

Thomas Cox reviews A Monster Calls, a children's novel that has been making a commotion in the literary world as adults reading to their children realise they're enjoying the novel more than they probably should.

The Last Supper

By James Bithell

Julie Green talks to Lucie Parker about painting death row inmates' dying wish.

Review: GamePlan

By James Bithell

GamePlan is entertaining, never ceasing to amuse, but the plot lacked complexity and intricacy. Lucie Parker reviews.

Review: Woman in Black

By James Bithell

Celia Scruby reviews the thrilling play Woman in Black.

Review: Fusion La Mer: Turn of the Tides

By James Bithell

An injection of humour and fun gave a new edge to this year's Fusion, but the show lacked the flow and slickness of previous years.

Review: Kiss Me Kate

By James Bithell

Elements of farce, clever humour and sharp choreography made up for a wavering plot line in this hit West End show. Tom Witherow reviews.
